Laws ch. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This action is brought in the Somerville District Court pursuant to the Massachusetts District Court jurisdictional statutes because the amount in controversy (damages for personal injury, medical expenses and lost wages) is within the monetary limits of this Court and this is the proper venue as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Somerville, Massachusetts.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231 (procedures for civil actions and various tort-related provisions).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260 (statute of limi.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260 (statute of limitations for personal injuries — see generally ch. 260, § 2A).

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) — foundational case on proximate cause and foreseeability (persuasive authority routinely cited in Massachusetts negligence jurisprudence).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The opinion is the classic Cardozo formulation making foreseeability to the particular plaintiff central to the duty/proximate cause analysis in negligence, which is exactly why it is treated as a foundational proximate cause/foreseeability case nationwide, including in Massachusetts. Cardozo explicitly frames negligence and duty as relational, defined by the “range of reasonable apprehension,” and holds there is no liability where the harm to the plaintiff was not reasonably foreseeable. That aligns with the proposition that Palsgraf is a foundational case on proximate cause and foreseeability and routinely cited as persuasive negligence authority.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… These cases aside, wrong is defined in terms of the natural or probable, at least when unintentional… Here, by concession, there was nothing in the situation to suggest to the most cautious mind that the parcel wrapped in newspaper would spread wreckage through the station.… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us.”

Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562 (.proposition: Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562 (H.L.) — foundational duty in negligence (neighbor principle) (persuasive authority).

Kinsman v. City of Springfield, 368 Mass.raw_text: Kinsman v. City of Springfield, 368 Mass. 256 (1975)
Kinsman v. City of Springfield, 368 Mass.proposition: Kinsman v. City of Springfield, 368 Mass. 256 (1975) — Massachusetts SJC discussion of causation and foreseeability in negligence (representative of SJC jurisprudence analyzing proximate cause).
Kinsman v. City of Springfield, 368 Mass.case_name: Sullivan v. Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston
Kinsman v. City of Springfield, 368 Mass.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Kinsman v. City of Springfield and does not discuss negligence, causation, or foreseeability. It concerns will interpretation, acceptance of a charitable devise, and whether actions by Cardinal Cushing constituted acceptance or renunciation of a testamentary gift. It therefore does not provide any authority on proximate cause or foreseeability in Massachusetts negligence law and cannot support the stated proposition.
Kinsman v. City of Springfield, 368 Mass.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion in this opinion of negligence, causation, or foreseeability in tort; the opinion focuses instead on acceptance, renunciation, and construction of a charitable devise in a will.

Degnan v. District Court, 394 Mass. 776.proposition: Degnan v. District Court, 394 Mass. 776 (1985) — Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court discussion of negligence standards applicable to Massachusetts tort law (representative authority).
Degnan v. District Court, 394 Mass. 776.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on hazardous waste cleanup, public nuisance, restitution, and police power versus takings; it does not purport to generally discuss or define negligence standards in Massachusetts tort law. Negligence is mentioned only tangentially via secondary sources and Restatement sections in the context of nuisance, not as a representative or foundational authority on Massachusetts negligence doctrine. Therefore, citing Degnan as a general statement of Massachusetts negligence standards is inaccurate.
Degnan v. District Court, 394 Mass. 776.relevant_excerpt: “Harper and James discuss nuisance as grounded in negligence and state the rule as: ‘The occupier of land generally owes a duty of reasonable care to prevent activities and conditions on his land from injuring persons or property outside his land . . . .’ Id. § 27.19, at 1521. They further explain: ‘[The] imposition of affirmative duties on land ownership or occupation is not new. It is a recognition that ‘The occupation of land may involve disadvantages as well as advantages.’’ Id. at 1523.”
